work.p: The lines of poetry on this manuscript leaf are drafts of lines used in the opening poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, later titled "Song of Myself": "I find letters from God dropped in the street, and every one is signed by God's name, / And I leave them where they are, for I know that others will punctually come forever and ever" (1855, p. 54).

titleStmt.title: And I have discovered them
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The manuscript includes drafts of lines used in the first poem in that edition, titled "Leaves of Grass," eventually titled "Song of Myself."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: And now it seems the dark, uncut hair of graves
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

This leaf is held with another small leaf in plastic casing. The prose drafted on the back of these and several other related manuscript leaves includes ideas and phrases that resemble those used in "Unnamed Lands," a poem published first in the 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass.

revisionDesc.change: updated editorial note, work relations, transcription

lg.l:
And I have discovered them by night and by
day;
And every one is signed by His Name;

And I leave them where they are, for I know that
others will punctually come as long as I live,

del.l: And afterward wherever I am they will be forwarded to me
